Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Study of Ultra-High Brightness of Fluorescent Silica Nanoparticles for the use in Bio Imaging Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1242214
Sokolov

This EAGER proposal deals with fluorescent nanoparticles of unusually high brightness. Being a substantially new and radically different approach to making fluorescent nanoparticles, this research is considered to be high risk. At the same time, it is a high potential
payoff due to the importance of such particles for a broad range of photonic applications involving tagging, tracing, labeling, and particularly in biological imaging and sensing. High brightness of labeling particles is desirable to attain higher signal-to-noise ratio, and consequently, to increase sensitivity and/or speed of sensing, contrast of imaging, to decrease the limit of detection, etc. The merits of the proposed research are in the study of silica nanoparticles, which have unusually strong fluorescent emission; understanding the nature of this phenomenon; and investigating the limits of this approach for bio-imaging applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluorescent nanoparticles are used in a broad range of applications involving imaging, sensing, tagging, tracing, labeling, and particularly in biological and medical applications. Recently a new class of highly fluorescent (ultrabright) silica nanoparticles was discovered. Despite the observed brightness, the nature of these phenomena remained unclear. It required additional investigation to convince researchers and industry, as well to understand the limits and other potential use of these particles.

This high-risk/high return award has three objectives. The first objective of our project has been to study the nature of the phenomenon of unusually high fluorescence. The ultrabright fluorescent silica particles are made of silica which has nanoscopic cylindrical pores. Existing fluorescent dyes are physically encapsulated inside those pores. As we found, the dyes can be effectively “dissolved” inside of those pores a substantially higher concentrations that it is possible in just liquid solvent (like water or alcohols). A specific nanoscale environment inside silica particles prevents dye molecules from aggregation, and subsequent losing their fluorescent properties. This was confirmed by observing various dye characteristics including their spectra, fluorescence lifetime, quantum yield, anisotropy, etc. We found that the dye molecules are effectively frozen inside the silica channels, which prevents them moving freely along the channels. At the same time, the dye molecules are almost free to rotate. This creates a specific caging for each dye molecule. More accurate measurements of fluorescence were carried out, and confirmed the previous observations of unusually high brightness.

The second objective was to demonstrate new applications of these particles for bio-imaging and sensing applications. Here we created near infrared fluorescent nanoparticles (in collaboration with Prof. Achilefu from WUSL). These particles are ~2000x brighter that individual molecule encapsulated; and up to 4× brighter than QD800 commercial quantum dots emitting at 800 nm. From a fundamental knowledge, this is the first example when the dye increases its quantum yield after encapsulating. The second demonstration was building ultrabright nanoparticles capable of measuring temperature (in collaboration with J. Hoops from Dartmouth College). This is invaluable for hyperthermia treatment of cancer, in which the temperature control is paramount. An unexpected outcome of this award is in demonstration feasibility of development of a new type of photonic sensor based on the concept of photonic transistor.

Broader impact included the educational component. Three graduate students and two postdoctoral fellows were partially supported by this grant. New fiber-optic devices were created in the PI lab, which enhances physical infrastructure. The results were disseminated in the conference and publications. Total of 13 conference and seminar presentations (including 7 invited) were given. Four archival papers were published, five manuscripts are in preparation and to be submitted for publication soon. The technology was licensed to the university spinoff company for commercialization. A part of the results was used to generate preliminary results for a successful award from the US Air Force to create ultrabright near infrared nanoparticles with specific spectral characteristics. This is now heading towards final stage of commercialization (STTR Phases I and II). A grant application proposing development of a new type of photonic sensor was submitted.
